Award.AwardTitle: Aggregation of Hybrid Dynamical Systems for Demand Response Modeling and Analysis

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to establish theoretical foundations for aggregated load modeling under various demand response strategies. A hybrid system model with general nonlinear subsystem dynamics will be developed to characterize individual load dynamics. The main research thrust is to obtain a unified abstraction for different types of responsive loads under a variety of demand response scenarios. In addition, the project will also develop a general modeling framework to capture the aggregated dynamics of a large population of heterogeneous hybrid systems.
Intellectual Merit: This project is among the first that tries to develop a holistic aggregated modeling framework that can deal with various responsive loads and demand response strategies. It can address many important realistic challenges in a unified manner. Such a framework is the key to identify and address fundamental research challenges in aggregated load modeling, and will enable formal analysis and design of demand response strategies.
Broader Impacts:
Demand response is a key technology to enable high penetration of renewable generations of the future power grid. This project will yield fundamental tools for reliable large-scale deployment of demand response programs. In addition, the project will also impact a number of education and outreach activities such as participation of undergraduate and under-represented students in research, inclusion of research results into courses, involvement of high school students. Close partnership with the Metro Early College High School at Columbus, OH will also be established during this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many electric loads, such as residential HVACs (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) and PEVs (Plug-in Electric Vehicles), can be equipped with smart local controllers that can modify their power consumptions in response to some coordination signals (e.g. price, direct load control signal, or power system frequency). Coordination of a large population of such responsive loads is an important paradigm of demand response programs and can provide various services to the power grid, such as power capping, energy arbitrage, and frequency regulation. Aggregate load modeling is concerned with characterizing the aggregate flexibility of responsive loads. The problem is of fundamental importance for systematic analysis and design of demand response strategies. It is challenging due to the various kinds of uncertainties about individual load models and the complex interplay between the load dynamics and their local response/control rules. The goal of this project is mainly twofold. First, we aim to establish theoretical foundations and principles for aggregate load modeling problems. Second, we want to develop efficient ways to compute aggregate models for important classes of responsive loads and study their applications in power systems.

One main outcome of this project is the development of a unified theoretical framework for aggregate load modeling. Existing aggregate load models in the literature are often based on specific types of loads under specific demand response scenarios. Some of these methods are based on heuristic ideas and intuitions; it is often hard to justify and compare their performances and advantages. In this project, we developed a general framework for aggregate load modeling based on a unified underlying principle. The key message is that most responsive loads under demand response programs can be described by a hybrid dynamical system that involves coupled continuous and discrete dynamics. A large population of such hybrid systems can be modeled as a stochastic hybrid system. Aggregate load modeling can be viewed as deriving the state density evolution (or its approximation) of the corresponding stochastic hybrid system model. Based on this principle, we are able to derive a unified aggregate load model that contains many important results in the literature as special cases. In addition, the generality of our model allows for easy incorporation of new modeling scenarios that have not been studied in the literature, such as nonlinear load dynamics, random mode switching (to account for unmodeled uncertainties on mode transitions), aggregation with deferrable loads, among others. These features can enable a larger range of applications for aggregate load modeling.

Another outcome of this project is the development of a simple geometric approach to characterize the aggregate flexibility for both thermostatically controlled loads and deferrable loads. This geometric approach can be viewed as an approximation of the unified aggregate model mentioned above. It can be easily incorporated into the current practice of power system operations. The operation of the power system relies on energy and ancillary service markets. Market decisions are made by solving optimization problems that maximize social welfare subject to some physical constraints such as power flow constraints on the transmission network and generator’s power rating and ramping constraints, among others. Currently, market participants mainly involve generators as their physical behaviors can be easily described by some linear constraints. As we move to the future power grid with high penetration of renewables, it is desirable to have demand-side participants to help balance the grid. The key challenge for demand-side market participation lies in the uncertainties of loads. Our geometric aggregate model provides an effective way to overcome such challenge. Through aggregation of a large number of residential loads, the aggregate power consumption flexibility can be accurately characterized by simple linear inequalities. Such inequalities can be easily incorporated into the market optimization problem, enabling demand-side participation in the market and leading to more efficient operations of the bulk power system.  

 The results of this project have been disseminated through conference presentations and journal publications. The project also resulted in useful analytical and numerical tools to obtain aggregate load models. These models will enable systematic design of demand response strategies for the future power grid and has a potential to improve the sustainability of our society. The project has also impacted various education activities at the Ohio State University. Some of the results have been used as examples in the investigator’s class ECE7850 Hybrid Systems: Theory and Applications. Several graduate students have received training through the project.
